facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 153 of 1955 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 153 of 1955. Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and decree dated August 30, 1954 of Allahabad High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 540 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and decree dated August 30, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 540 of 1951,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and decree dated March 31, 1951 of Additional Civil Judge, Mathura in Suit No. 19 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated March 31, 1951, of the Court of the Additional Civil Judge, Mathura, in Suit No. 19 of 1950.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 5, 1958 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. December 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave

facts.text: Landlord (appellant) was plaintiff in trial court, tenant (respondent) was defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The landlord who was the plaintiff in the trial court is the appellant before us and the tenant who was the defendant is the respondent.

facts.text: In 1938 respondent took accommodation on rent at Rs. 21-4 as monthly for stacking timber.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of this appeal are that in 1938 the respondent took on rent the accommodation in dispute which is termed a tal on a monthly agreed rent of Rs. 21-4 as. and was using the same for the purpose of stacking timber.

facts.text: Portion of accommodation was covered godown with three walls and kucha roof.

anchor.surface_text: A portion of it was a covered godown which had three walls and a kucha roof.

facts.text: On January 28, 1950, appellant applied to House Allotment Officer under s.3A for fixation of reasonable rent.

anchor.surface_text: On January 28, 1950, the appellant made an application to the House Allotment Officer under s. 3-A of the United Provinces  Temporary  Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947  U. P. III of 1947   hereinafter termed the Act  for the fixation of reasonable annual rent

facts.text: Appellant alleged constructed new godown 80 x 25 x 11 feet in January 1949 at respondent's instructions, spent large sum, entitled to Rs.165 monthly.

anchor.surface_text: He therein alleged that in January 1949 he had constructed anew a big godown 80 x 25 x 11 feet according to the instructions of the respondent and expended a fairly large sum of money on it and was therefore entitled to a monthly rent of Rs. 165.

facts.text: House Allotment Officer fixed rent at Rs.35 per mensem on February 18, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The House Allotment Officer fixed on February 18, 1950, the rent at Rs. 35 per mensem which on review was raised on May 25, 1950, to Rs. 40 per mensem.

facts.text: On review, rent raised to Rs.40 per mensem on May 25, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: which on review was raised on May 25, 1950, to Rs. 40 per mensem. He held that the accommodation was not a newly constructed accommodation as the respondent had been a tenant from 1938.

facts.text: HAO held accommodation not newly constructed as tenant from 1938, increase based on new construction added.

anchor.surface_text: He held that the accommodation was not a newly constructed accommodation as the respondent had been a tenant from 1938. He determined the increase of rent on the basis of the building that was added by the new construction.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit under s.5(4) alleging new construction of ferro-concrete roof 80x25 ft at respondent's request, agreed enhanced rent, proper rent Rs.115/month.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon instituted a suit on the ground of inadequacy of the reasonable annual rent under s. 5 4  of the Act alleging that he had constructed the portion of the accommodation anew and put up ferro-concrete roof 80 x 25 feet and that the construction was undertaken at the request of the respondent who had agreed to pay enhanced rent

facts.text: Respondent denied construction at his request, said for another storey, no new construction after June 30, 1946 for his part, space diminished by pillars and lower roof.

anchor.surface_text: The defence was that there was no construction at the request of the respondent but it had been undertaken in order to put up another storey on the top of the old building that as far as the accommodation in possession of the respondent was concerned there was no new construction of accommodation after June 30, 1946 that the ferro-concrete roof had in no way benefited him,

facts.text: Additional Civil Judge held suit maintainable, new construction made accommodation bigger, fixed rent at Rs.55-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Civil Judge found that the suit was not barred because of the Act that the suit against the order of the House Allotment Officer was maintainable that newly constructed accommodation on the whole was bigger and more spacious than the old kacha hall and that the accommodation had increased and after taking into consideration the amount spent on the construction be increased the reasonable adequate rent to Rs. 55-8-0.

facts.text: Respondent filed revision under s.115 CPC to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decree of the learned Judge the respondent took a revision to the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court allowed revision, held no new construction for respondent's accommodation after June 30, 1946, suit not maintainable, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the opinion that if the accommodation was a new construction erected after June 30, 1946, the suit was maintainable ... the construction could not be called new construction and therefore S. 3-A was not applicable and as no suit lay at the instance of the landlord to have the agreed rent enhanced, the tenant was only liable to pay the agreed rent and no more. The revision petition was therefore allowed and the suit of the appellant was dismissed.

facts.text: Main controversy: Whether High Court could interfere in revision under s.115 CPC with trial court's decision on date of construction.

anchor.surface_text: The main controversy raised between the parties was whether the High Court could, in revision under S. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, interfere with this decision of the trial court.

facts.text: Appellant contended date of construction within jurisdiction of trial court, HC cannot interfere if erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that it was within the jurisdiction of the Additional Civil Judge to decide the question of the date of construction of the accommodation and in doing so he could decide rightly or wrongly as the matter was within his jurisdiction and therefore the High Court had no power to interfere merely because in its opinion the decision was erroneous.

facts.text: Respondent contended date of construction is jurisdictional fact.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents counsel on the other hand submitted that the decision of the court as to the date of construction was in this case a jurisdictional fact i.e. a fact which went to the root of the jurisdiction of the court because unless the accommodation was held to have been a new construction made after June 30, 1946,

facts.text: Accommodation constructed before July 1, 1946 has reasonable annual rent defined differently under s.2(f).

anchor.surface_text: Reasonable annual rent in the case of accommodation constructed before July 1, 1946, means  1 if it is separately assessed to municipal assessment, its municipal assessment plus 25 per cent thereon

facts.text: For accommodation constructed on or after July 1, 1946, reasonable rent determined under s.3A.

anchor.surface_text: and in the case of accommodation constructed on or after July 1, 1946, means the rent determined in accordance with section 3-A .

facts.text: Trial court held portion newly replaced treated as new accommodation, suit maintainable under s.5(4).

anchor.surface_text: the learned Civil Judge held- I am therefore of the opinion that portion of the building in suit which has been newly replaced must be treated as a new accommodation, and hence this Court can determine its rent under the provisions of s. 5 4 .
Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and decree dated August 30, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 540 of 1951,
This is an appeal by special leave against the decision of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad passed in revision under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.text: whether the High Court could, in revision under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, interfere with this decision of the trial court

anchor.surface_text: The main controversy raised between the parties was whether the High Court could, in revision under S. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, interfere with this decision of the trial court. The respective contentions were these The appellant contended that it was within the jurisdiction of the Additional Civil Judge to decide the question of the date of construction of the accommodation and in doing so he could decide rightly or wrongly as the matter was within his jurisdiction and therefore the High Court had nopower to interfere merely because in its opinion the decision was erroneous. In other words, this question was merely one of the facts in issue between the parties unconnected with jurisdiction.

issues.text: whether the decision of the court as to the date of construction was in this case a jurisdictional fact i.e. a fact which went to the root of the jurisdiction of the court because unless the accommodation was held to have been a new construction made after June 30, 1946, the suit under s. 5(4) would not lie

anchor.surface_text: The respondents counsel on the other hand submitted that the decision of the court as to the date of construction was in this case a jurisdictional fact i.e. a fact which went to the root of the jurisdiction of the court because unless the accommodation was held to have been a new construction made after June 30, 1946,

issues.text: the question for determination was whether the accommodation had been constructed before or after June 30, 1946, and that if it was constructed before that date the suit was incompetent and if after, the suit would lie
Whether the suit is not maintainable in view of any provisions of the Act No. 3 of 1947 ?

anchor.surface_text: The relevant issues raised were - Whether the suit is number maintainable in view of any provisions of the Act No. 3 of 1947 ? Whether the suit after the fixation of rent by the House Allotment Officer is number maintainable ? What should be the reasonable and proper rent of the accommodation in suit ? The learned Additional Civil Judge found that the suit was number barred because of the Act that the suit against the order of the House Allotment Officer was maintainable that newly constructed accommodation on the whole was bigger and more spacious than the old kacha hall and that the accommodation had increased and after taking into consideration the amount spent on the construction be increased the reasonable adequate rent to Rs. 55-8-0.

issues.text: Whether the suit after the fixation of rent by the House Allotment Officer is not maintainable ?

The learned Additional Civil Judge found that the suit was number barred because of the Act that the suit against the order of the House Allotment Officer was maintainable that newly constructed accommodation on the whole was bigger and more spacious than the old kacha hall and that the accommodation had increased and after taking into consideration the amount spent on the construction be increased the reasonable adequate rent to Rs. 55-8-0. Against this decree of the learned Judge the respondent took a revision to the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

The learned Additional Civil Judge found that the suit was number barred because of the Act that the suit against the order of the House Allotment Officer was maintainable that newly constructed accommodation on the whole was bigger and more spacious than the old kacha hall and that the accommodation had increased and after taking into consideration the amount spent on the construction be increased the reasonable adequate rent to Rs. 55-8-0. Against this decree of the learned Judge the respondent took a revision to the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The High Court was of the opinion that if the accommodation was a new construction erected after June 30, 1946, the suit was maintainable and- the High Court could number interfere with the finding of the Civil Judge as to the amount of rent.

issues.text: as to whether the High Court had correctly interfered under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure with the order of the Civil Judge

arguments.claim: High Court had no power to interfere in revision under s.115 CPC merely because trial court's decision on date of construction was erroneous; it was within jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that it was within the jurisdiction of the Additional Civil Judge to decide the question of the date of construction of the accommodation and in doing so he could decide rightly or wrongly as the matter was within his jurisdiction and therefore the High Court had no power to interfere merely because in its opinion the decision was erroneous.

arguments.court_reasoning: Date of construction is a jurisdictional fact; wrong decision leads to exercise of jurisdiction not vested.

arguments.claim: House Allotment Officer decided date of construction in favour under s.3A, establishing right to suit; High Court cannot review correctness in revision u/s.115 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: He also contended that the House Allotment Officer having decided in his favour the question of the date of construction which s. 3-A of the Act authorises him to decide, his right to bring the suit was established and therefore the High Court could not in revision under s. 115, Code of Civil Procedure, go into the correctness of that decision.

arguments.court_reasoning: Suit under s.5(4) independent; requires jurisdictional fact of new construction after 30.6.1946.

arguments.claim: Date of construction is a jurisdictional fact going to root of jurisdiction; without new construction after June 30, 1946, no right of suit under s.5(4), court has no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents counsel on the other hand submitted that the decision of the court as to the date of construction was in this case a jurisdictional fact i.e. a fact which went to the root of the jurisdiction of the court because unless the accommodation was held to have been a new construction made after June 30, 1946, the appellant would be bound by the agreed rent and would have no right of suit under s. 5(4) and the court would have no jurisdiction to entertain the suit.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; explained via scheme of Act; trial court wrongly assumed jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Portion of building newly replaced must be treated as new accommodation; suit maintainable under s.5(4) for fixation of rent.

anchor.surface_text: I am therefore of the opinion that portion of the building in suit which has been newly replaced must be treated as a new accommodation, and hence this Court can determine its rent under the provisions of s. 5(4).

arguments.claim: s.115 CPC allows interference if subordinate court exercises jurisdiction not vested due to erroneous jurisdictional fact.
Landlord constructed new godown Jan 1949 per tenant instructions; entitled Rs.165 monthly.

anchor.surface_text: He therein alleged that in January 1949 he had constructed anew a big godown 80 x 25 x 11 feet according to the instructions of the respondent and expended a fairly large sum of money on it and was therefore entitled to a monthly rent of Rs. 165.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: eaded that the suit was number maintainable under the Act and that numbersuit companyld be filed after the order of the

arguments.court_reasoning: HAO rejected full claim; not entirely new.

holdings.text: at the instance of the landlord the suit was only maintainable if it was based on the inadequacy of the reasonable annual rent and for that purpose the necessary jurisdictional fact to be found was the date of the construction of the accommodation
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of U.P. Act III/1947 (ss.2(f), 3A, 5(4)) distinguishes pre/post-1946 constructions; landlord suit limited to inadequacy of reasonable rent (post-1946 via s.3A), not agreed rent enhancement

holdings.text: if the court wrongly decided that fact and thereby conferred jurisdiction upon itself which it did not possess, it exercised jurisdiction not vested in it
holdings.reasoning_summary: Erroneous decision on jurisdictional fact results in subordinate court exercising non-vested jurisdiction or failing to exercise vested jurisdiction, attracting High Court revision power u/s.115 CPC

holdings.text: The High Court, in our view, approached the question quite correctly when it stated that the question for determination was whether the accommodation had been constructed before or after June 30, 1946, and that if it was constructed before that date the suit was incompetent and if after, the suit would lie
holdings.reasoning_summary: Maintainability of suit u/s.5(4) turns on whether construction post-June 30, 1946 (reasonable rent u/s.3A) or pre (agreed rent governs); pre-1946 renders suit incompetent

holdings.text: the High Court had correctly interfered under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure with the order of the Civil Judge
holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court wrongly found post-1946 new construction (jurisdictional fact), assuming non-vested jurisdiction; falls under s.115(a) permitting revision

holdings.text: Section 115, Code of Civil Procedure, empowers the High Court, in cases where no appeal lies, to satisfy itself on three matters- (a) that the order made by the subordinate court is within its jurisdiction (b) that the case is one in which the court ought to exercise its jurisdiction (c) that in exercising the jurisdiction the court has not acted illegally, that is, in breach of some provision of law or with material irregularity
holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of scope of s.115 CPC revision jurisdiction per precedents (Venkatagiri Ayyangar)

precedents.citation: Queen v. Commissioner for Special Purposes of the Income Tax 1

anchor.surface_text: in the Queen v. Commissioner for Special Purposes of the Income Tax 1 - When an inferior companyrt or tribunal or body, which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first established by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to companysider, what powers it will give that tribunal or body. It may in effect say that, if a certain state of facts exists and is shown to such tribunal or body before it proceeds to do certain things, it shall have jurisdiction to do such things, but number otherwise. There it is number for them companyclusively to decide whether that state of facts exists, and, if they exercise the jurisdiction without its existence, what they do may be questioned, and it will be held that they have acted without jurisdiction.

precedents.case_name: Queen v Commissioner for Special Purposes of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between two classes of cases regarding jurisdiction of inferior courts or tribunals to determine preliminary jurisdictional facts

precedents.citation: Venkatagiri Ayyangar v. Hindu Religious Endowment Board, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Per Sir John Beaumont in Venkatagiri Ayyangar v. Hindu Religious Endowment Board, Madras 1 . Therefore if an erroneous decision of a subordinate companyrt resulted in its exercising jurisdiction number vested in it by law or failing to exercise the jurisdiction so vested or acting with material irregularity or illegality in the exercise of its jurisdiction the case for the exercise of powers of revision by the High Court is made out.

precedents.case_name: Venkatagiri Ayyangar v Hindu Religious Endowment Board Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court can interfere in revision under s.115 CPC if subordinate court exercised jurisdiction not vested, failed to exercise vested jurisdiction, or acted illegally or with material irregularity

precedents.citation: Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury 2

anchor.surface_text: In Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury 2 , the subordinate companyrt gave an erroneous decision that the loan was a companymercial loan and therefore refused to exercise jurisdiction vested in it by law and the Privy Council held that it was open to the High Court to interfere in revision under s. 115.

precedents.case_name: Joy Chand Lal Babu v Kamalaksha Chaudhury
precedents.cited_proposition: Erroneous decision by subordinate court refusing to exercise jurisdiction on jurisdictional fact allows High Court interference in revision under s.115

anchor.surface_text: The cases of Babu Ram v. Munnalal 1 and Hari Bhikaji v. Naro Vishvanath 2 , may be mentioned as cases in which a subordinate companyrt by its own erroneous decison  erroneous, that is, in the view of the High Court , in the one case on a point of limitation and in the other on a question of res judicata, invested itself with a jurisdiction which in law it did number possess and the High Court held, wrongly their Lordships think, that it had numberpower to interfere in revision to prevent such a result.

precedents.cited_proposition: Example where High Court wrongly refused to interfere when subordinate court assumed jurisdiction erroneously

anchor.surface_text: The cases of Babu Ram v. Munnalal 1 and Hari Bhikaji v. Naro Vishvanath 2 , may be mentioned as cases in which a subordinate companyrt by its own erroneous decison ...

precedents.cited_proposition: Example where High Court wrongly refused to interfere when subordinate court assumed jurisdiction erroneously on res judicata

precedents.citation: Keshardeo Chamria v. Radha Kissen Chamria 3

anchor.surface_text: In Keshardeo Chamria v. Radha Kissen Chamria 3 both these judgments of the Privy Council as also the previous judgments in Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh 4   and Balakrishna Udayar v. Vasudeva Aiyar 5  were reviewed and it was held that s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure applies to matters of jurisdiction alone, the irregular exercise or number exercise of it or the illegal assumption of it.

precedents.case_name: Keshardeo Chamria v Radha Kissen Chamria
precedents.cited_proposition: s.115 CPC applies to jurisdictional errors including erroneous decision on jurisdictional fact leading to assumption of jurisdiction not vested

precedents.citation: Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh 4

precedents.cited_proposition: An adjudication by a Judge having jurisdiction over the subject matter is, if no defect appears on the face of it, to be taken as conclusive of the facts stated therein

precedents.citation: Joy Chandlal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury 1

anchor.surface_text: As we have held above, at the instance of the landlord the suit was only maintainable if it was based on the inadequacy of the reasonable annual rent and for that purpose the necessary jurisdictional fact to be found was the date of the companystruction of the accommodation and if the companyrt wrongly decided that fact and thereby companyferred jurisdiction upon itself which it did number possess, it exercised jurisdiction number vested in it and the matter fell within the rule laid down by the Privy Council in Joy Chandlal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury 1 .

precedents.case_name: Joy Chand Lal Babu v Kamalaksha Chaudhury
precedents.cited_proposition: The matter falls within the rule allowing revision where subordinate court exercises jurisdiction not vested due to erroneous finding on jurisdictional fact

anchor.surface_text: The revision petition was therefore allowed and the suit of the appellant was dismissed.
